title: New Cannondale Synapse integrates SmartSense, adds storage and gets more aero
content:
Cyclist
New Cannondale Synapse integrates SmartSense, adds storage and gets more aero

Cannondale has launched the sixth generation Synapse Carbon endurance bike, which it says is more aero and more compliant than its predecessor. There’s more integration too, with hidden cables and in-frame storage.

SmartSense lighting and radar is still an option, but the battery is now housed inside the down tube, the lights are smaller and brighter and all SmartSense bikes include the radar.

For the first time, there’s a premium carbon LAB71 option for the Synapse, with the LAB71 frame also used for the Synapse Carbon 1 bike. The higher spec frame is claimed to reduce frame weight relative to the standard modulus carbon frame by 150g to under 1,000g. There’s another 50g pared off the fork weight.

Prices for the five new Synapse Carbon specs available at launch range from $3,500 / €3,499 and top out at $15,800 / €15,799, with UK prices and two further specs to be announced.

If you want to be one of the first to try out the new Synapse, the bike will be available to test ride at Cyclist Track Days on 17th May in London and 7th June in Leeds. Get your tickets here.

‘The right bike for most riders’

Now on its sixth generation across 20 years, Cannondale asserts that the new Synapse is the right bike for most riders. It was the bike used by Lachlan Morton on his FKT 14,200km lap of Australia in 30 days, 9 hours and 59 minutes.

‘The Synapse helped to define the endurance category,’ says Andreas Krajewski, Cannondale’s marketing manager for road and gravel. ‘It was raced over the cobbles and it brought real innovation to the table of road riding.

‘Now the rules of endurance road bikes are being reimagined. From tyre width to integrated technology, tri bars to extreme saddle positions, anything goes.’

Krajewski claims the new Synapse is a bike that can equally be built up light and fast or with lights and bags for long distance travels, pushing the boundaries of what road riding can be.

Now more aero

With the new Synapse, Cannondale says it has designed the bike to elevate its performance to the level of the SuperSix Evo, while keeping the comfort and accessibility of its endurance platform. That means that, geometry-wise, the new Synapse remains taller and shorter than the SuperSix Evo. 

It’s also aimed to preserve the family resemblance, with a similar look to the recently launched SuperX gravel race bike, in particular, with the skinny mid-section to the seat tube, which Cannondale says has increased compliance at the saddle by 20% over the outgoing model.

Although not as aero as the current SuperSix Evo, Cannondale says that the new Synapse is as fast as that bike’s third generation. It has used similar heavily truncated aerofoil shapes to the SuperSix Evo frame. Rather than an elongated tail, their profile is close to 1:1, which the brand claims allows it to maintain frame stiffness, compliance and low weight while reducing drag by 30% over the last generation bike.

Although it isn’t aimed at off-road riding, the 42mm tyre clearance in the frame and 48mm in the fork, up from 35mm in the last Synapse iteration, would allow you to fit chunky tyres for all-road riding too. 

There’s the full range of mudguard, rack and top tube bag mounts, although there are only the two classic bottle cage mounts.

Easier to live with

As well as the family resemblance, Cannondale uses similar tech in the new Synapse to its other bikes. As with the last generation Synapse and all Cannondale’s other recent bikes, there’s a BSA bottom bracket. 

Cannondale has also switched from a round steerer tube to its Delta Steerer, as used in the SuperSix Evo, so there’s internal cabling and the bike is compatible with its full range of stems. That’s allowed it to fit top spec bikes with its SystemBar R-One one-piece carbon bar/stem, also found on higher specs of the SuperSix Evo. The non-round steerer also reduces the head tube’s frontal area for aero benefits.

The new Synapse uses the same thru-axles, UDH mech hanger and D-shaped seatposts as elsewhere in its range as well. 

More integrated SmartSense 2

The most divisive feature of the last generation Synapse was undoubtedly its SmartSense lighting and radar setup, which also found its way onto some specs of the previous generation Topstone. 

Commenting on SmartSense in his review verdict for the 2022 Synapse, Cyclist tech editor Sam Challis said, ‘I would urge Cannondale to reconsider the application of the SmartSense system. To lighten it, to more seamlessly integrate it, and maybe to not include it as standard on all models.’

The 500g or so extra weight was a downside, which he reckoned neutered the bike uphill somewhat.

Cannondale has listened, because SmartSense is an option on the new Synapse and it’s now much better integrated, both in design and functionality, although it hasn’t provided a weight figure for SmartSense 2. 

With the new Synapse, the SmartSense battery is housed under a hatch in the down tube, so it doesn’t affect the bike’s looks. Cannondale has also reworked the lights and radar, so that they’re less prominent and better integrated. One disadvantage of the greater integration is that you can’t retrofit SmartSense, due to the internal routing. The rear light/radar still gets in the way of a saddle bag too, although the integrated storage may make this less of an issue.

The battery capacity has doubled, so there’s a 24-hour claimed runtime, while the front light is smaller but brighter, emitting 800 lumens in non-StVZO format or 400 where it’s StVZO compliant. The rear light and radar are now one unit and, unlike the previous generation bike, SmartSense-equipped bikes all come with both the radar and rear light.

The battery itself includes an LED, making it easier to see inside the cavity once the hatch is opened.

Even with the battery in place the new Synapse still provides extra capacity for a toolkit or emergency rations, with Cannondale providing a stash bag to keep items together. It reckons that around two-thirds of the down tube’s internal cavity is available for storage. 

In the case of SRAM-equipped bikes, the battery also powers the derailleurs. Cannondale has engineered the system so that shifting will keep working even if battery capacity is too low to power the lights, so you’re unlikely to end up riding a single-speed. A SmartSense battery with 5% remaining charge still has equivalent capacity to a standard AXS derailleur-mounted battery, Cannondale says.

The Cannondale wheel sensor can be configured to wake SmartSense automatically when it detects that the bike is moving and turn it off at the end of a ride. It forms part of an integrated system with the enhanced Cannondale app, which allows you to configure the system and change lighting patterns, brightness and the flash pattern when a vehicle is detected approaching from behind. 

The app also offers ride tracking, can pair with a heart rate monitor and other devices and can provide data on electric bike systems for Bosch-equipped e-bikes.

Cannondale Synapse range and prices

The Cannondale Synapse lineup will eventually include seven bikes, as well as a LAB71 frameset-only option. All are equipped with 32mm tyres, despite the 42mm available clearance. 

At launch, Cannondale will offer four 2x Shimano-equipped specs as well as the LAB71 spec with 1x SRAM Red XPLR AXS. 

Size-wise there are seven options: 44, 48, 51, 54, 56, 58 and 61. Cannondale uses its Proportional Response Construction tube sizing and carbon layup, to ensure that riders of different sized frames experience a similar ride feel.

Cannondale Synapse LAB71 SmartSense

  • Frame/fork: LAB71 Hi-mod Carbon
  • Groupset: SRAM Red XPLR AXS w/ power meter 40t, 10-46t
  • Wheelset: Reserve 42 | 49 Turbulent Aero on DT Swiss 180 hubs
  • Tyres: Vittoria Corsa Pro Control 32mm
  • Bar/stem: Cannondale SystemBar R-One one-piece
  • Saddle: Fizik Vento Argo 00 Carbon
  • Seatpost: Cannondale C1 Aero 27 Carbon
  • Price: $15,800 / €15,799

Cannondale Synapse Carbon 1

  • Frame/fork: LAB71 Hi-mod Carbon
  • Groupset: Shimano Ultegra 50/34, 11-34t
  • Wheelset: Reserve 42 | 49 Turbulent Aero on DT Swiss 350 hubs
  • Tyres: Vittoria Corsa Pro Control 32mm
  • Bar/stem: Cannondale SystemBar R-One one-piece
  • Saddle: Fizik Vento Argo R5 
  • Seatpost: Cannondale C1 Aero 27 Carbon
  • Price: $9,200 / €9,199

Cannondale Synapse Carbon 2

  • Frame/fork: Synapse Carbon
  • Groupset: Shimano Ultegra 50/34, 11-34t
  • Wheelset: DT Swiss ERC 45 carbon on DT Swiss 350 hubs
  • Tyres: Vittoria Rubino Pro IV 32mm
  • Bars: Vision Trimax Aero alloy
  • Stem: Cannondale C1 Conceal alloy
  • Saddle: Fizik Vento Argo X5
  • Seatpost: Cannondale C1 Aero 27 Carbon
  • Price: $7,200 / €7,199

Cannondale Synapse Carbon 2 SmartSense

  • Wheelset: DT Swiss R470 alloy rims on Shimano RS470 hubs
  • Tyres: Vittoria Rubino Pro IV 32mm
  • Bars: Vision Trimax Aero alloy
  • Stem: Cannondale C1 Conceal alloy
  • Saddle: Fizik Vento Argo X5
  • Seatpost: Cannondale C1 Aero 27 Carbon
  • Price: $4,500 / €4,499

  • Frame/fork: Synapse Carbon
  • Groupset: Shimano 105 50/34, 11-36t
  • Wheelset: DT Swiss R470 alloy rims on Shimano RS470 hubs
  • Tyres: Vittoria Zaffiro Pro V 32mm
  • Bars: Vision Trimax Compact TT alloy
  • Stem: Cannondale C1 Conceal alloy
  • Saddle: Fizik Terra Argo X7
